title: Producer Price Inflation Reaches 23.1%
text:
17:58 CET Producer Price Inflation Reaches 23.1% By Daily Guide 
Dr Philomena Nyarko Ex-factory prices of goods and services for all industry increased on average by 23.1 percent in June 2015, 4.3 percentage points higher than 18.8 percent recorded in May 2015. 
The monthly change rate for June 2015 was 4.4 percent. 
Price inflation in the mining and quarrying sub-sector increased by 4.6 percentage points over the May 2015 rate of 25.4 percent to record 30.0 percent in June 2015. 
Dr Philomena Nyarko, Government Statistician, who disclosed this yesterday in Accra, said manufacturing, which constitutes more than two-thirds of total industry, increased by 5.2 percentage points to record 21.9 percent. 
She said the manufacture of rubber and plastic products recorded the highest inflation rate of 58.7 percent while the manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products recorded the lowest producer price inflation rate. 
The utilities sub-sector recorded an inflation rate of 20.8 percent in June 2015, representing a marginal increase of 0.2 percentage point over the May 2015 rate of 20.6 percent. 
From June 2014, the producer price inflation began an upward trend and increased consistently over three months to record 48.6 percent in August 2014. 
However, the rate consistently declined to 19.2 percent in March 2015. 
It increased to record 19.5 percent in April, 2015 and declined to 18.8 percent in May 2015. 
It, however, increased again in June 2015 to record 23.1 percent. 
Petroleum subsector The inflation rate in the petroleum sub-sector was 44.7 percent in June 2014. 
It reached a peak of 77.3 percent in July 2014 and thereafter fluctuated until November, 2014 when it recorded a rate of 61.1 percent. 
Subsequently, the rate steadily declined to record -8.7 percent in March 2015 and -9.6 percent in May 2015 as a result of base drift effect and the decrease in ex-refinery prices of petroleum products. 
The rate, however, increased in June 2015 to record -0.01 percent as a result of the increase in petroleum prices. 
By Samuel Boadi
